text: Patient: I don’t. Doctor: I think that you know it primed your immune system to help us for the rest of the way here. Uh it’s not something that we can measure, but it’s clearly um something that I’m glad you did. And it certainly didn’t cause the cancer to spread any more or anything like that. Patient: Well my quality of life is significantly better. Doctor: Good, good. How well are you controlling your urine right now? Patient: I’m good. I have a um. Family Member: He has a panty liner. Patient: I have a panty liner. Just like in case I sneeze, cough. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That’s I mean I’m full exercising. Doctor: Uh hum. That’s okay, good. So you’re not leaking when you exercise? Patient: No, no. no. Doctor: Oh good. Okay, so really going forward, there are sort of two approaches that folks take. The standard of care is that you um would get uh radiation to your pelvis, uh and most people, given the amount of disease you have down there, we also recommend that you get hormone therapy with the radiation. Um uh, so one standard of care would be radiation alone; the second standard of care would be radiation plus hormone therapy generally for two years, which sucks, quite frankly.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Then I would just proceed with the Xtandi and start it. Okay? (Sound Door closes) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The other piece of this that’s an unknown piece is, we have some sets that the people who got testosterone, even the ones that didn’t respond to it, seemed to have a better response to drugs like Xtandi or Zytiga afterwards. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And our, our idea is maybe that the cells have gotten used to being low testosterone and they’ve kind of adjusted. Then we put them in high testosterone, they adjust to that- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it makes them susceptible when we go back down again. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s sort of like not quite a selling point. Doctor: But the potential could be a bonus. I’m hopeful that today your testosterone will come, will be lower. Patient: Um hum.

text: Family Member: I may have to go sign an order. Doctor: He wrote down the questions? That’s pretty good. Family Member: Well, yeah. I mean, I am his daughter. What are some of the things that I should really be on the lookout for, the fatigue? Doctor: I think really just the tiredness. If you feel like you’re more off balance, you know, let’s say it’s weeks from now, that’s something also that’s pretty subtle that can come up just like that (snaps) Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’d have to make sure there’s, you know, nothing really going on but sometimes people feel a little bit off kilter. Patient: Vertigo, or-? Doctor: Uh, no. It’s almost just like, you know, you stand up and you’re ooh. Not like it’s spinning, but you just don’t have a sense of where you are, and then you right yourself, but, obviously, we don’t want you to fall. Um, so if you start to feel like, you know, there’s some unsteadiness, we need to know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s a lot of paperwork if you fall.

text: Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: - some people actually do have an improvement in their PSA, their PSA is go down and, but when we give it to everybody, we don't really see an effect. What we found is that there are probably people with a certain genotype, meaning that certain changes in their DNA, which are like totally normal, about a quarter of the population has this. Patient: Mm. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: Those people are more likely to respond, it seems. So with this trial is first we check your genotype. So that's step one. And then if you are the particular genotype, which, for the purposes of we'll just call it AA. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: That means that you're eligible for the study- Patient: Okay. Doctor: -and then you get randomized to the muscadine grape skin or placebo. And if you are on the placebo arm, if your PSA, if it's if the placebo is not working, then you get the muscadine grapeseed. Okay, so, eventually everybody on the trial can get the therapy. Okay? If you're not this genotype and you're not eligible because we don't think that you'll, you'd have any benefit. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But to see if you would be eligible for the study, you'd have to first join the study, then we do this genotype testing. And then if you're eligible, about 25% of the population is eligible. So you have a one in four shot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then if you're eligible, I think that that would actually be a reasonable option. Okay. The other trial is a trial of alaparib. This study is, a study of, it, so it's a PARP inhibitor. This medicine is used in breast cancer and ovarian cancer, and it's used sometimes in advanced prostate cancer, and we're studying to see if it can be used early on without hormone therapy in prostate cancer. Just to spare people from prostate cancer. The MAP study, the muscadine grape skin has very few side effects gas, upset stomach, this one can cause nausea and vomiting and can sometimes cause your blood counts to go lower. This is like an expensive medicine that is provided but usually you have to go through insurance for all the clinical trials. So this and this one, I'm not positive that you're eligible for yet either. Okay. So those are the two clinical trial options that we have for biochemical recurrence.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I must say that outside of a trial, I haven’t been that excited about the radium, to be honest, in the patients I’ve treated. Family Member: Why? Doctor: Uh, it’s been kind of toxic to the bone marrow. People have kind of gotten beat up when they take it and feeling really tired. Um, and in the trials where it got approved, uh, it didn’t really have big effects on the PSA. It didn’t have big effects on shrink, you know, changing the bone. The only readout was the people who got it seemed to live long. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, you know, we- Patient: Is that how it works when they give, give the, uh, the seeds in the prostate? Is that, is that similar to that process? Doctor: But we haven’t done the seeds, uh, we just do them alone. But we haven’t, you know, probably somebody’s going to try that concept, which is seeds and some kind of immunotherapy as well. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: There has been, uh, some trials where what they did is they took a patient who has spots in the bone and radiated one spot and give it immunotherapy. There’s some signal that the immunotherapy works better when you do that. Uh, that you’re sort of damaging the cells with radiation and that seems to get your own immune system- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Kind of excited. Patient: Um hum.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
